review.title: Massively Increasing TIMEX3 Resources: A Transduction Approach
review.abstract: Automatic annotation of temporal expressions is a research challenge of great interest in the field of information extraction. Gold standard temporally-annotated resources are limited in size, which makes research using them difficult. Standards have also evolved over the past decade, so not all temporally annotated data is in the same format. We vastly increase available human-annotated temporal expression resources by converting older format resources to TimeML/TIMEX3. This task is difficult due to differing annotation methods. We present a robust conversion tool and a new, large temporal expression resource. Using this, we evaluate our conversion process by using it as training data for an existing TimeML annotation tool, achieving a 0.87 F1 measure -- better than any system in the TempEval-2 timex recognition exercise.

sections.heading: 2.1. Comparable Work
sections.text: In this section we describe them and how our work differs. Saquete and Pustejovsky (2011) describe a technique for converting TIMEX2 to TIMEX3 annotations and present the T2T3 tool as their implementation. Since some things commented as TIMEX2s are no longer considered part of temporal expressions in TimeML and are instead assigned to other functions, T2T3 creates not only TIMEX3s, but also additional TimeML elements. T2T3 is evaluated with TimeBank (Pustejovsky et al., 2003) and 50 ACE TERN documents. This work was novel, but its practical evaluation is limited to the TimeBank corpus and a small selection of the ACE TERN data.

sections.heading: 2.2. TIMEX2 Datasets
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

sections.heading: 3. Method
sections.text: The original T2T3 tool worked well with a subset of the ACE TERN corpus and TimeBank. However, upgrades were needed to cope with linguistic variations in new texts. In this section, we detail our handling of the source data sets and our solutions to linguistic and technical shortcomings of the original T2T3 when applied to these records. Our general approach consists of three phases. First, we prepare the source data sets in a uniform format, running T2T3 over each document individually. Finally, we wrap the resulting annotations in TimeML headers and footers and validate them. This process produces a corpus based on gold standard annotations, although it cannot be called the gold standard as the machine-generated annotations have not all been manually checked and corrected.

sections.heading: 3.1. Running T2T3
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Nested expressions
sections.text: As discussed in Section 2, TIMEX2 generates annotations larger than 3 that may be nested (as in Example 2) and T2T3 does not handle them; they must be mapped to multiple TIMEX3 annotations, possibly with an associated anchorTimeID attribute or temporal relationship. This would look like: (8) < TIMEX3 tid = "t1" type = "DATE" value = "1999-W23" > the week long duration, two single specific days, and the temporal relations between all three. This would look like: (8) < TIMEX3 tid = "t1" type = "DATE" value = "1999-W23" > the week < SIGNAL sid = "s1" of < / SIGNAL sid > of < / SIGNAL > T2 "type =" t2. "

sections.heading: 3.1.3. Brevity
sections.text: We automatically shorten long periods of time. TIMEX3 annotations are minimal - that is, including the minimum amount of words that can describe a temporal expression - where TIMEX2 can contain whole phrases. Even after reducing the length of annotations that contain temporal substructors, in some cases a significant amount of text may remain. To accomplish this, we implement the reduction of long TIMEX2s to only the TIMEX3 functional part. This is done by measuring the distribution of TIMEX3 token lengths in gold standard corpora and determining a section. This distribution is shown in Table 2. All TIMEX2s of six tokens or more not yet covered by the above algorithms are analyzed syntactically, and are then reduced to the largest constituting chunk that is shorter than six tokens and contains a time bar word, giving preference to the left arguments. Example 9 shows a long TIMEX2 days (shortended from these days to four).

sections.heading: 3.1.4. Technical changes
sections.text: To speed up processing, we switched to NLTK5 for PoS tagging, a maximum entropy-based tagger trained at Penn Treebank. We also discontinued lemmatization, as it is never used in practice. To further speed up, we implemented a timex phrase PoS tagging cache, which has reduced execution times by two orders of magnitude. Generally, the tool has become more robust and now handles a wider range of texts and provides more precise TimeML annotations. Our work has led to a publicly available tool ranging from a public mercurial repository 6.5See http: / / www.nltk.org /. 6See http: / / bitbucket.org / leondz / t2t3.

sections.heading: 3.2. Document post-processing
sections.text: After conversion of the body of text into TIMEX3, each document in TimeML is provided with an XML header and packed into < TimeML > elements. Each document is then checked by a DOM parser for its basic validity, then strictly checked against TimeML-XSD for display errors, and finally verified at a high level with CAVaT (Derczynski and Gaizauskas, 2010), resulting in consistent and TimeML-valid documents.

sections.heading: 4. Resource creation
sections.text: In this section we describe the results of the conversion of all of the above mentioned corpora. Table 3 shows the scope of TIMEX3 and other TimeML element annotations generated by the conversion of TIMEX2. The number of TIMEX2 annotations is generally somewhat smaller; this may be caused by the removal of nested temporal expressions where the outside time is removed during the conversion. To show the time composition of the resulting corpora, Table 4 shows the distribution of the timex type in native and converted corporations; they introduce 18,803 new TIMEX3 annotations, of which 4,343 are in "web-grade" data - i.e. data from blogs, forum newsgroups and Wikipedia, including 2,676 from Wikiwars (Wikipedia) and the remainder from ACE2005 - 675 from newsgroups, 20 from community forums and 972 from text crafted for automatic web development, which is an important resource for the consistent web.

sections.heading: 5. Evaluation
sections.text: We evaluate the impact of our new resources by measuring the performance of a state-of-the-art time detector, TIPSem-B (Llorens et al., 2010), which achieves competitive performance when trained via the TimeBank and AQUAINT corpora. We extend its training set to include our newly generated data. Our assessment includes time detection (both detection and interpretation) using the following data: 1. New (T2T3) data when trained on the basis of previous data (TimeBank + AQUAINT) to show the "difficulty" of the new data in light of current TIMEX3 training resources; 2. A mixture of previous and T2T3 data with an 80 / 20 training / test split to show how the detection method handles the new data (TimeBank + AQUAINT); 3. Prior data with an 80 / 20 training test / split to show how the detection method handles the new data; and 2.

sections.heading: 5.1. General recognition
sections.text: The Timex detection performance of our T2T3 data from systems trained with previous Newswire-only corpora was low, with an F1 measurement of less than 50%. This suggests that existing resources are insufficient to develop generic Timex detection models that are effective outside the Newswire genre. However, existing detection methods are able to adapt to the new corpora as some of the training data from itas is available; an 80 / 20 training / test split of combined Newswire / T2T3 periods led to F1 measurements in the 1970s.

sections.heading: 5.2. Improving performance on newswire
sections.text: It is useful to measure performance against a TempEval-2-like task - the detection of time intervals in the TimeBank / AQUAINT TimeML corpora. To this end, we determined an 80 / 20 training / test split of TBAQ (TimeBank + AQUAINT) and measured system performance against a model learned from the training data. Subsequently, the large T2T3-generated resource is added to the training data, re-learning the detection model, and evaluating performance. As the results show, the larger set of more varied training data represents an improvement over the TimeBank set. Recall increases significantly at the expense of some precision between both evaluation measures, which is consistent with what would be expected given a much broader range of expressions in the training data. The end result for TempEval-2 F1 is greater than the best value achieved during the TempEval-2 evaluation task.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: In order to detect and overcome problems with the TIMEX2 / TIMEX3 conversion, we have developed a robust tool for converting TIMEX2 resources to TimeML / TIMEX3. Thus, we have created a TIMEX3 resource of an order of magnitude that contains more annotations than all previous resources put together. It contains new information about time expressions and is useful for training automatic time lapse annotation systems. We have made both the transfer tool and the TIMEX3 annotation results available as part of a public repository. Version 1.0 of the data is available as a single release on the project page (distribution licenses apply).

sections.heading: 6.1. Future Work
sections.text: Since TIMEX2 resources exist in languages other than English (especially Spanish and German), T2T3 can be expanded to accommodate these and English. Furthermore, the wide variety of phrasing of temporal expressions in the corpora presented in this essay, together with its TIMEX3 annotations, is a significant boon to those who deal with the problem of Timex normalization.

sections.heading: 6.2. Acknowledgments
sections.text: The authors would like to thank Lisa Ferro from MITRE Corporation for her kind help in providing TIMEX2 resources. The first author would also like to acknowledge the support of the UK Engineering and Physical Science Research Council in the form of a PhD scholarship. This work has also been supported by the Spanish Government in the projects TIN-2009-13391-C04-01, MESOLAP TIN2010-14860, PROMETEO / 2009 / 119 and ACOMP / 2011 / 001.

referenceMentions.context: TIMEX2 (Ferro et al., 2004) is dedicated to timex annotation.
TimeML (Pustejovsky et al., 2005) is a later standard for all aspects of temporal annotation.
Manual creation of fully temporally annotated resources is a complex and intensive task (Setzer and Gaizauskas, 2001).
To this end, some recent work has explored the complex issue of converting TIMEX2 corpora to TIMEX3 (Saquete and Pustejovsky, 2011).
Manual temporal annotation is a complex, tiring and errorprone process (Setzer and Gaizauskas, 2001).

The TIDES TIMEX2 standard (Ferro et al., 2004), preceded by the STAG timex descriptions (Setzer, 2001), formally defines how to determine what constitutes a temporal expression in discourse and further defines an encoding for temporal expressions.

, 2004), preceded by the STAG timex descriptions (Setzer, 2001), formally defines how to determine what constitutes a temporal expression in discourse and further defines an encoding for temporal expressions.
As part of TimeML (Pustejovsky et al., 2005), which is a rich annotation schema designed to capture a complete range of temporal information, TIMEX3 focuses on minimally-expressed timexes.

The work in this paper centres on applying a transducer to TIMEX2 resources to bring them into a LAF-compliant format (Ide and Romary, 2002) (our TIMEX3 annotations are valid ISO-TimeML (Pustejovsky et al.

The work in this paper centres on applying a transducer to TIMEX2 resources to bring them into a LAF-compliant format (Ide and Romary, 2002) (our TIMEX3 annotations are valid ISO-TimeML (Pustejovsky et al., 2010)).
Saquete and Pustejovsky (2011) describe a technique for converting TIMEX2 to TIMEX3 annotations and present the T2T3 tool as an implementation of it.
Corpora are still produced in TIMEX2 format (Mazur and Dale, 2010; Strötgen and Gertz, 2011).
Corpora are still produced in TIMEX2 format (Mazur and Dale, 2010; Strötgen and Gertz, 2011).
TIMEX2 resources were produced in volume for the ACE TERN tasks (Ferro, 2004) and temporal information extraction research conducted shortly after.
The ACE2005 corpus4 (Strassel et al., 2008) includes text of multiple genres annotated with a variety of entity types, including timexes.
As part of an effort to diversify the genres of timexannotated corpora, WikiWars (Mazur and Dale, 2010) is a 20-document corpus of Wikipedia articles about significant wars, annotated to TIMEX2.
The conversations were originally in Spanish and comprised that language’s part of the Enthusiast corpus (Suhm et al., 1994), which were later translated into English (by humans).
Aside from TimeBank and AQUAINT, other relevant TIMEX3 corpora are the TempEval-2 international evaluation exercise dataset (Verhagen et al., 2010) and the TimenEval TIMEX3 dataset (Llorens et al.
, 2010) and the TimenEval TIMEX3 dataset (Llorens et al., 2012).
For a discussion of the nuances of these resources and this standard, see Mazur and Dale (2010). The ACE2005 corpus4 (Strassel et al.
The Semantic web poses a tough temporal annotation problem (Wilks, 2008).
Annotation standards have been proposed – TIMEX3 is suitable for temporal expressions, and OWLTIME (Hobbs and Pan, 2004) is a temporal ontology suitable for the semantic web.
When it comes to dealing with text quality on the web, even semi-structured resources such as Wikipedia pose challenges (Völkel et al., 2006; Maynard et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2010).
When it comes to dealing with text quality on the web, even semi-structured resources such as Wikipedia pose challenges (Völkel et al., 2006; Maynard et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2010).
When it comes to dealing with text quality on the web, even semi-structured resources such as Wikipedia pose challenges (Völkel et al., 2006; Maynard et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2010).
Our development cycle consisted of processing source documents with T2T3 and then validating the output using a TimeML corpus analysis tool (Derczynski and Gaizauskas, 2010).

For this, we use an approach that first identifies the signal (according to the definition and investigation of temporal signals provided in Derczynski and Gaizauskas (2011)) and then determines which parts of the remaining parts of the phrase (“chunks”) are a TimeML TIMEX3 and EVENT.

Based on a corpus-based survey of temporal signal phrase meanings (Derczynski and Gaizauskas, 2011), we prefer monosemous words (giving preference to the most frequently-occurring ones) followed by polysemous words in descending order of likelihood of being a temporal signal.

Each document is then processed by a DOM parser to check for basic validity, then strictly evaluated compared to the TimeML XSD to check for representation errors, and finally verified at a high level with CAVaT (Derczynski and Gaizauskas, 2010).
We evaluate the impact of our new resources by measuring the performance of a state-of-the-art timex recogniser, TIPSem-B (Llorens et al., 2010).

Performance is reported using both entity recognition precision and recall (strict), as well as the TempEval-2 scorer, which uses a token-based metric instead of entity-based matching (see Verhagen et al. (2010) for details).

metadata.abstractText: Automatic annotation of temporal expressions is a research challenge of great interest in the field of information extraction. Gold standard temporally-annotated resources are limited in size, which makes research using them difficult. Standards have also evolved over the past decade, so not all temporally annotated data is in the same format. We vastly increase available human-annotated temporal expression resources by converting older format resources to TimeML/TIMEX3. This task is difficult due to differing annotation methods. We present a robust conversion tool and a new, large temporal expression resource. Using this, we evaluate our conversion process by using it as training data for an existing TimeML annotation tool, achieving a 0.87 F1 measure – better than any system in the TempEval-2 timex recognition exercise.
